Hmm, why are we serializing modelSchema?   Isn't this used when we serialize a model and send to AppSync for doing an update mutation? I don't think we want to send that to AppSync, right?   I guess we might need to serialize it into the local DB though.   Do we need different Gson instances for SQLite vs AppSync now?
Another thing I notice is there is no ModelSchemaAdapter in this PR, which means ModelSchema, ModelField, and AuthRule etc, will all be serialized via reflection of their field names.  That means we won't be able to make breaking changes to them in the future, otherwise we could break SQLite deserialization.   Maybe that's fine, but we should at least take that into consideration.

The ModelSchema is only ever used locally on the client, as metadata. It never gets saved to the SQL tables, and it never gets passed to AppSync.
At various points in the code, I need to rectify the shape of the serializedData -- iterating over its fields, to understand the type of each one. There are two ways to achieve this:

Just store the modelName, and then retrieve the ModelSchema for that modelName, from the ModelSchemaRegistry;
Store the entire ModelSchema next to the SerializedModel. This is a little wasteful, but it's pretty convenient, and it only ever happens in memory. Whenever I need to understand the schema for the data, it's right next to it.

I don't think, strictly speaking, there is a need to serialize the ModelSchema. But, it happens to be convenient (at least) in test code. Since I had a deserialize, it felt ~right to implement the serialize method at the same time, in the same place, to show the symmetry of the operation.
Thanks for clarifying!   Since it isn't getting saved in SQLite, this is not really a concern any more!
